docs.abstract: article on econ woes presently besetting Sri Lanka; nation is experiencing critical food shortage, galloping inflation and is torn by internal dissension; fundamental reason for nation's plight seen stemming from spiraling cost of food imports coupled with stationary export earnings; blend of Govt mismgt of farmland, meager incentives to growers, take-over of private estates under land reform and residue of colonial tradition has left nation virtually begging for rice and wheat; nations is approximately $2-billion in debt to other countries and is uncreasingly unable to obtain loans because of its poor credit position; is expected to spend 2/3 of its foreign exchange earnings, approximately $300-million, on imports of rice and wheat, whose cost has tripled during last 2 yrs; problem is further exacerbated, according to Govt critics, by ideological addiction to takeovers, coupled with tradition of far-reaching soc-welfare measures, which are extravagant and perhaps crippling; many Ceylonese conclude that decades-old system of free med care, free educ and free food supplements each wk to every nontaxpayer is economically unfeasible, especially in population that has doubled in 25 yrs; map (L)

docs.abstract: Portuguese Foreign Min Ernesto Melo Antunes has taken off for talks with EEC in hope of getting emergency aid for Portuguese econ; says he thinks Portuguese situation finally has settled down enough to make it possible to discuss financial problems; EEC, for nearly 1 yr, has been discussing aid for Portugal to help it make transition to partnership with W Eur as dem but decision on credits and loans repeatedly has been postponed because of pol and mil uncertainties; Antunes says he plans to go to NY after EEC talks in Luxembourg, says that, while US trip primarily is connected with UN, he also will discuss finance with unidentified 'leading people' in NY; aid is expected from EEC and possibly from US but new Portuguese Govt's inability to develop econ plans because of pol uncertainties is still major concern; internal politics represents great handicap for Lisbon Govt's efforts to revive econ; Labor Min Tomas Rosa says major problem is belief of many workers that 'revolution means higher wages and shorter hours'; econ experts say that workers' expectations of immediate benefits from 'popular govt' plus Govt's subsidies to cos to prevent layoff's has begun to distort econ; Industrialists Confed head Antonio Vasco de Melo says that he considers difference between rapid rise in wages and slower rise in prices reasonable; estimates wages have gone up 40% and prices about 20%; Portuguese and foreign employers and econ experts, however, agree that it soon will be necessary lo impose wage-price freeze if stalled econ is to get moving; external factors also have aggravated econ difficulties; tourism and remittances from Portuguese workers abroad, 2 sources of revenue in past, had prevented deficits in Portuguese balance of payments; trade deficit in '74, yr of revolution, was $2-billion and over-all payments deficit was $600-million, compared with trade deficit in '73 of $900-million and over-all surplus of $345-million in balance of payments; Govt officials and foreign econ observers agree that pol and soc climate is major factor depressing econ (L)

docs.snippet: With the economy's tides not waiting for any man, not even a President-elect, Ronald Reagan's policy and policy statement crew passed the week sharing in the  spirit of the Stockman-Kemp scenario for ''avoiding a G.O.P. economic Dunkirk.'' As for the
docs.lead_paragraph: With the economy's tides not waiting for any man, not even a President-elect, Ronald Reagan's policy and policy statement crew passed the week sharing in the spirit of the Stockman-Kemp scenario for ''avoiding a G.O.P. economic Dunkirk.'' As for the letter of the proposal, however, serious disagreements began to emerge. As outlined last month, the plan called for a 100-day ''campaign'' to legislate budget and spending cuts. Something like that was presumably what James A. Baker 3d, incoming White House chief of staff, had in mind when he said last week that Mr. Reagan was considering declaring an ''economic emergency'' on Inauguration Day to dramatize the situation's seriousness and the administration's determination to act.

byline.original: By EDWARD COWAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary G. William Miller contends that no national economic emergency exists but that talk of one by aides to President-elect Ronald Reagan ''may be creating that emergency.'' In a multipronged criticism of the incoming administration, Mr. Miller said the President-elect seemed to be putting tax cuts ahead of spending cuts. He said such a ''looseness in fiscal policy'' would increase the Federal budget deficit and could ''drive interest rates through the roof.''

headline.main: HAITI, FACING ECONOMIC CRISIS, ARRESTS MAJOR CRITICS

docs.snippet: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 30 -The Government rounded up journalists, politicians and human rights activists over the weekend in an attempt to turn attention from Haiti's worsening economic crisis before a Dec. 8 meeting of international banking and aid

byline.original: By JO THOMAS

docs.lead_paragraph: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 30 -The Government rounded up journalists, politicians and human rights activists over the weekend in an attempt to turn attention from Haiti's worsening economic crisis before a Dec. 8 meeting of international banking and aid organizations, foreign diplomats and Haitians said today. Attention has been focused on Haiti since Haitian refugees returned two weeks ago from the Bahamian island of Cayo Lobos, saying they preferred the desert island to life here. The incident, which many Haitians called a national disgrace, set off commentary on the unequal distribution of wealth here.

headline.main: SAN FRANCISCO - The roots of the economic crisis in Poland lie in agricultural policies the Government has followed since World War II.

docs.snippet: An uneven balance of power between urban and rural interests, in the Government and the Communist Party, created policies that undermined the Polish economy and left Poland caught between a rock and a hard place, politically beholden to the Soviet

byline.original: By Eleanor M. LeCain

docs.lead_paragraph: An uneven balance of power between urban and rural interests, in the Government and the Communist Party, created policies that undermined the Polish economy and left Poland caught between a rock and a hard place, politically beholden to the Soviet Union and economically beholden to the West. The Soviet Union offers ideological guidance enforceable by troops while Western financial institutions suggest conflicting economic measures backed by capital. The resolution of this dilemna will occur when rural people have a stronger voice in Government and Party decision making. When the Communists came to power after the war, the only organized opposition came from peasant groups. To woo peasant support, the Communists enacted a land redistribution program. Then they attempted to collectivize, sending in urban people unfamiliar with rural conditions.

headline.main: WARSAW SHUFFLES CABINET MINISTERS IN ECONOMIC CRISIS

docs.snippet: Poland's Prime Minister announced a sweeping reorganization of the Cabinet today in a move apparently designed to help the Government cope more effectively with the country's economic crisis.   The announcement by Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski

byline.original: By Reuters

docs.lead_paragraph: Poland's Prime Minister announced a sweeping reorganization of the Cabinet today in a move apparently designed to help the Government cope more effectively with the country's economic crisis. The announcement by Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski came just hours before the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, arrived from Moscow for what the Soviet press agency Tass said would be ''a brief friendly visit.'' The Cabinet changes were announced at a session of Parliament by Prime Minister Jaruzelski, a general, who is also Minister of Defense. The changes involved the ouster of eight ministers, the appointment of five new ones and the reassignment of four others.

headline.main: NEW TURKISH PREMIER FACES ECONOMIC CRISIS

docs.snippet: The sharp rise in the cost of living and the low salaries of the great majority of Turks constitutes the number one problem facing Turkey's new civilian Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal and his Government after more than three years of strict military

byline.original: By MARVINE HOWE

docs.lead_paragraph: The sharp rise in the cost of living and the low salaries of the great majority of Turks constitutes the number one problem facing Turkey's new civilian Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal and his Government after more than three years of strict military rule. Ayse, for example, is one of the best students in third-year medical school at Ankara University, but says she is afraid she will have to quit and get a job to help support the family. Living costs have become unbearable for many average Turks like Ayse's father, a retired air force noncommissioned officer. He says he cannot find other employment and his pension of $100 a month is simply not enough for him, his wife and three school-age children to live on.

headline.main: BEIRUT'S LATEST TRAUMA IS ECONOMIC CRISIS

docs.snippet: Rarely can one pinpoint a day, let alone the minute, when a country's economy began sliding into recession. But ask Lebanese businessmen when their economy started heading into a tailspin and many will respond with little hesitation: 1:03 p.m., Apr

byline.original: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Rarely can one pinpoint a day, let alone the minute, when a country's economy began sliding into recession. But ask Lebanese businessmen when their economy started heading into a tailspin and many will respond with little hesitation: 1:03 p.m., April 18 - the moment the United States Embassy in Beirut was destroyed. ''In the opinion of both businessmen and the average citizen, the Lebanese economy is now in its deepest crisis since the civil war started in 1975,'' said Elias S. Saba, a former finance minister and now chairman of Allied Business Bank. ''The turning point was the explosion of the American Embassy. It wasn't the cause of the downturn. It simply tore away the curtain before everyone's eyes and made them realize that things in Lebanon were not as rosy as we wanted to think.'' The day after the embassy was blown up, recalls Johann Naschek, owner of the busy Myrtom House restaurant, ''Our business dropped by 20 percent. It hasn't recovered; it was just a real shock.''

headline.main: ECONOMIC CRISIS IN ISRAEL MAY REMOLD THE COUNTRY

docs.snippet: For the first time since the founding of the Israeli state in 1948, an economic crisis, much more than any immediate military threat, has come to preoccupy the nation.   ''Before, they used to say that every Israeli had to be a general,'' said Yaa

byline.original: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the founding of the Israeli state in 1948, an economic crisis, much more than any immediate military threat, has come to preoccupy the nation. ''Before, they used to say that every Israeli had to be a general,'' said Yaacov Fisher, senior economist at the Bank of Israel. ''Now they say that every Israeli has to be an economist.'' The crisis, economists say, has been produced partly by excessive military burdens but also by the peculiar structure of Israel's political system, the economic restraints of Zionism, years of living beyond the nation's means and sheer mismanagement by some of its governments. A Different Israel to Emerge The Israel that emerges from the crisis, the analysts here contend, will be a different place, with a lower standard of living for its citizens, a lower military budget, some very high unemployment or a combination of the three. It will also be an Israel that is much more dependent on foreign creditors, in particular the United States.

headline.main: DEBT ACCORD SOUGHT

docs.snippet: The Government of Raul Alfonsin, which restored democracy after eight years of a repressive military dictatorship, is struggling to pull Argentina back from the brink of financial collapse.     ''We have an economic situation of such extreme gravi

byline.original: By LEONARD SILK, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Government of Raul Alfonsin, which restored democracy after eight years of a repressive military dictatorship, is struggling to pull Argentina back from the brink of financial collapse. ''We have an economic situation of such extreme gravity that it has no precedent in Argentine history,'' said Horatio Jaunarena, Under Secretary of Defense and a member of the Alfonsin team trying to reform the structure of Argentine society. Amid this economic crisis, the new Government faces opposition from Peronist labor unions that have been allied to the military. The Government's agonizing problem is whether it can stick to democratic means, provide the better living standards it has promised to working people and still bring inflation under control. Backed by Business Leaders So far, the Alfonsin administration is getting a remarkable degree of support from many business leaders, who view it as trying to lay the foundation for a more stable democratic society.

As the stock market was plunging last week, stirring echoes of the 1929 crash, some wondered what plans the Government had for meeting an economic disaster. In fact, according to past and present Federal officials, there are no plans to use in a stock market collapse.

Yet the conditions for such assistance are stirring anxiety in this nation, which historically prides itself on self-reliance. docs.lead_paragraph: The international space station will fly without a crew for months longer than planned because of Russia's economic crisis, a top NASA official said today, though completion of the station on time is still possible. A NASA astronaut, William Shepherd, and two Russians were supposed to be the station's first settlers in May 1998, six months after the launching of its first component. But now they will not get there until October 1998 at the earliest because of the Russians' inability to launch a service module on time, said the manager of the space station program, Randy Brinkley.

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders gathered for the annual Asia Pacific economic summit meeting declared today that stringent domestic economic policies and closer international monitoring are the only way to contain the financial emergencies that have crippled South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand in recent months and have endangered Japan's already weakened financial system. While previous Asia Pacific summit talks have made traditional declarations about the importance of sound economic policies, the Asian financial crisis that hung over this meeting like a sullen cloud will put pressure on member nations to turn these platitudes into policy. Three of the 18 members of the Asian-Pacific Economic Community, South Korea, Indonesia, and Thailand, have asked the International Monetary Fund for emergency loans, and they must follow I.M.F. conditions for austerity in order to get that money.

byline.original: By ANDREW POLLACK

docs.lead_paragraph: For several years, Mattson Technology Inc. in Fremont, Calif., embodied the Silicon Valley dream. Sales tripled from one year to the next. When the company's stock was first sold to the public in 1994, about a dozen executives became millionaires. One year the company took all employees and their families to Lake Tahoe for a Christmas vacation. But this year, the Christmas party will probably be pot luck. Mattson's sales have dropped in half from their peak last year. One round of layoffs at the 400-employee company has occurred and another is in the works. And the company's stock, which traded above $16 in July 1997, has fallen to $5.375, making employee stock options worthless.

headline.main: Coping With Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: The world's economic situation is perilous, and there is little doubt that there will be pain and suffering in many countries during the next few years. But the problems need not lead to world recession, let alone depression. With time and wisdom, th
docs.lead_paragraph: The world's economic situation is perilous, and there is little doubt that there will be pain and suffering in many countries during the next few years. But the problems need not lead to world recession, let alone depression. With time and wisdom, the problems can be overcome. The gathering in Washington of the world's financial leaders last week proved to be long on alarming rhetoric and short on action. The dismal forecasts contrasted sharply with what the visiting central bankers and finance ministers could see around them in a prosperous country where it is lies, not layoffs, that dominate the news. But the United States is beginning to feel effects of the Asian collapse, particularly in manufacturing, and has reason to worry as Latin American economies are damaged by high interest rates imposed to slow the exodus of foreign investors. Similarly, Western Europe's export-led growth is threatened.

byline.original: By Edwin McDowell

docs.lead_paragraph: BARRING a last-minute rescue, Philippine Airlines, Asia's oldest scheduled carrier, will shut down at midnight tonight. This means passengers who until now have flown the airline's daily nonstop flight between Los Angeles and Manila, or the thrice-weekly nonstop flights between San Francisco and Manila, will have to make other arrangements. But no other arrangements from the United States will include nonstops. Northwest Airlines, for example, has daily flights to Manila from nine United States cities, including New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco. But all of them connect through Tokyo, which after a layover of about two hours requires a change of plane and an additional four and a half hours of flying. Northwest's daily flight from Memphis to Manila via Tokyo also requires a stop and a change of plane in Seattle.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your April 21 front-page article on the crisis in Japan's economy made me wonder who has really lost perspective, as we in the United States continue to ride our own ''bubble economy.'' I fail to see how it takes ''political will'' to lay off workers, bankrupt companies and ''snuff out the hopes of the kindly old ladies who run rice shops and futon stores.''

headline.main: 2 South Korean Companies Respond to Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: Two of South Korea's four largest chaebols, the octopus-like conglomerates that dominate this country's corporate landscape, provided details today of sweeping revamping plans that raised almost as many questions as they answered.    Hyundai, the lar

byline.original: By STEPHANIE STROM

docs.lead_paragraph: Two of South Korea's four largest chaebols, the octopus-like conglomerates that dominate this country's corporate landscape, provided details today of sweeping revamping plans that raised almost as many questions as they answered. Hyundai, the largest chaebol, shelved plans for an integrated steel mill that has long been a pet project of its founder, Chung Ju Yung. The LG Group, third largest of the four giants, said it would shed 90 marginal lines of business by 1999, paring some 2.4 trillion won from its balance sheet.

docs.abstract: World financial markets have brought Indonesia's currency and $225 billion economy to brink of collapse; opponents of Pres Suharto, who has ruled Indonesia for 32 years, have called for him to step down; Suharto has agreed to allow International Monetary Fund to direct minute details of his country's daily life; he has agreed to break up cartels that have made his family and loyalists millionaires; while Suharto's future seems suddenly in play, it is far from sure that Indonesia's economic crisis marks beginning of end of his long rule (M)

headline.main: Sudden Weakness Aside, Suharto Looks to Outlast Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: For 32 years, Asia's longest-serving leader, President Suharto of Indonesia, has bent this sprawling, fractious and astoundingly diverse nation to his will.    While he has sometimes been questioned, his control has never been seriously challenged. H

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and SETH MYDANS

docs.lead_paragraph: For 32 years, Asia's longest-serving leader, President Suharto of Indonesia, has bent this sprawling, fractious and astoundingly diverse nation to his will. While he has sometimes been questioned, his control has never been seriously challenged. He has never hesitated to use force, favoritism or political manipulation. But in the last decade, it has been Indonesia's remarkable prosperity -- built partly on a cascade of foreign investment -- that has cemented his control.

docs.snippet: WHEN Krakatoa blew apart in 1883 in one of the world's most cataclysmic explosions, it took three months before the first evidence of the eruption off Java was visible in America, in the form of brilliant sunsets created by volcanic ash circling the

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Krakatoa blew apart in 1883 in one of the world's most cataclysmic explosions, it took three months before the first evidence of the eruption off Java was visible in America, in the form of brilliant sunsets created by volcanic ash circling the globe. When the rupiah, Indonesia's currency, melted down 10 days ago, it took only minutes to feel the reverberations. Currencies and stock markets dropped throughout Asia, and Wall Street took a shellacking. Within hours, President Clinton was on the phone to Asia's longest-serving leader, Suharto, telling him he had only days to get his economic act together.

byline.original: By Mark Landler

docs.lead_paragraph: STOCK markets from Seoul to Singapore soared yesterday, extending a rally that many analysts here say is proof that foreign investors are returning in large numbers to the recession-ravaged economies of Asia. ''Something fundamental is happening,'' said Miron Mushkat, the head of global economics and strategy at Indocam Asia Asset Management in Hong Kong. ''The markets are telling us that the Asian crisis is over. We are moving from deeply dark territory into the land of the light.''

headline.main: Waves From Brazilian Economic Crisis Pound a Uruguayan Beach Resort

docs.snippet: World War II and the Spanish Civil War devastated much of Europe, but this breezy corner of Uruguay's coastline prospered from a flock of well-heeled exiles who came here to escape.    The 1970's and 80's brought death squads and hyperinflation to th

byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

docs.lead_paragraph: World War II and the Spanish Civil War devastated much of Europe, but this breezy corner of Uruguay's coastline prospered from a flock of well-heeled exiles who came here to escape. The 1970's and 80's brought death squads and hyperinflation to the Southern Cone, but when Argentina's rich whisked their capital out of Buenos Aires they brought it to Punta del Este and sunk it into the mansions and condominiums that made this sprawling resort South America's answer to Miami Beach, the Hamptons and the French Riviera.

docs.abstract: Resistance to economic reform by group of powerful state governors creates dangerous impasse in Brazil's struggle to stabilize economy; latest crisis was touched off when Minas Gerais Gov Itamar Franco set unilateral 90-day moratorium on repayment of state's estimated $13.5 billion debt to Government; other opposition governors score Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso's austerity plan and seek to renegotiate their debt (M)

headline.main: Brazil's Economic Crisis Pits President Against Governors

docs.snippet: As the Brazilian Government struggles to restore the stability of an economy under siege, the most intractable critics have emerged not abroad, but here at home, where the resistance to reform by a group of powerful state governors has created a dang

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Brazilian Government struggles to restore the stability of an economy under siege, the most intractable critics have emerged not abroad, but here at home, where the resistance to reform by a group of powerful state governors has created a dangerous impasse. The crisis that has shaken world stock markets, led to a draining of Brazil's foreign reserves and forced a 35 percent devaluation of its currency, was touched off on Jan. 6. That was when Itamar Franco, the newly inaugurated Governor of Brazil's second-most-populous state, Minas Gerais, announced a unilateral 90-day moratorium on repayment of his state's estimated $13.5 billion debt to the federal Government.

docs.abstract: Economic crisis that has shaken Brazil represents growing danger to hundreds of multinational companies that have flocked to country and invested billions of dollars in recent years; though all of Brazil is now reeling, once-flourishing automobile industry, centered in Sao Bernardo do Campo, was hit early and particularly hard; photo of laid-off workers who took over Ford Motor Co plant; map (M)

headline.main: Double-Edged Economic Crisis Whipsaws Brazil Workers and Companies

docs.snippet: For 22 years and 4 months, Luiz Porfirio Diniz reported daily to the bustling Ford do Brasil automotive plant here, where three different car models are manufactured. But then just before Christmas, he got the bad news he had been fearing ever since

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER

docs.lead_paragraph: For 22 years and 4 months, Luiz Porfirio Diniz reported daily to the bustling Ford do Brasil automotive plant here, where three different car models are manufactured. But then just before Christmas, he got the bad news he had been fearing ever since Brazilian interest rates shot to nearly 50 percent four months ago: He was one of 2,800 assembly-line workers being laid off. Employees took over the plant on Jan. 5 to protest that move, so Mr. Diniz still spends his day on the plant floor, playing dominos with his fellow workers. The stoppage means that Ford is no longer producing its daily quota of 1,000 cars, but the company has not moved against the workers -- perhaps because car sales are declining so dramatically in Brazil that Ford has the equivalent of nearly two months of production stockpiled in storage areas here.

docs.abstract: Gov Mike Foster of Louisiana, who enjoyed approval ratings of up to 80 percent in first months of his term, sees his popularity go into free fall since budget crisis developed earlier this year after several years of surpluses; to balance budget, sales tax on food was increased; even fellow Republicans criticize how Foster handled what became surprise fiscal emergency; photo (M)

headline.main: Statehouse Journal; Economic Crisis Costly For Louisiana Governor

docs.snippet: For a few high-flying months in his first term, Mike Foster might have been the most popular governor in America, riding a brief economic boom and his Harley-Davidson Road King to unheard-of approval ratings in the range of 70 percent to 80 percent.

byline.original: By DAVID FIRESTONE

docs.lead_paragraph: For a few high-flying months in his first term, Mike Foster might have been the most popular governor in America, riding a brief economic boom and his Harley-Davidson Road King to unheard-of approval ratings in the range of 70 percent to 80 percent. But the good years never seem to last long in Louisiana. Inevitably, they are overtaken by an extreme statewide poverty virtually unparalleled in the nation, along with an addiction to oil revenues that frequently run dry. When this year's state budget could not be balanced without a sales tax increase on food, Mike Foster fell back to earth, hard. And it is unclear whether the economy will allow him to ascend again in the last three years of his second term.

docs.snippet: Moving to restore badly shaken public confidence, the Turkish government appointed a longtime World Bank executive to the cabinet today and gave him broad responsibility to solve a financial crisis that has sent prices soaring and threatened to swamp

byline.original: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

docs.lead_paragraph: Moving to restore badly shaken public confidence, the Turkish government appointed a longtime World Bank executive to the cabinet today and gave him broad responsibility to solve a financial crisis that has sent prices soaring and threatened to swamp banks and business. News that Kemal Dervis, a Turk who has worked at the World Bank for the last two decades, would serve in the new post of minister of the economy was welcomed in the banking and business sectors, where he is well regarded for his knowledge of international finance.

docs.abstract: New and increasingly assertive civic movement has sprung up in Argentina, with thousands of middle-class people organizing and debating solutions to country's crisis; principal demand at these meetings and marches has been elimination of two-month-old government freze on bank accounts; Supreme Court just ruled that restrictions areunconstitutional and ordered them lifted, heartening movement's members; nonpartisan, nonviolent assembly movement is offspring of spontaneous street demonstations that forced Fernando de la Rua to resign presidency on Dec 20; to those who find themselves involved in civic life after years of passivity, Argentina's fundamental problem is not economic or even political; they say that country is confronting moral crisis more severe than any it has ever faced; they blame themselves for allowing corrupt politicians to steal country from them; photos (M)

headline.main: Roused by Economic Crisis, Argentina's Middle Class Finally 'Gets Involved'

docs.snippet: With its traditional political parties discredited by the country's collapse, Argentina is confronting a political vacuum. Daniel Algarbe is no politician, but he is convinced that he and thousands of middle-class people like him have found a way to

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER

docs.lead_paragraph: With its traditional political parties discredited by the country's collapse, Argentina is confronting a political vacuum. Daniel Algarbe is no politician, but he is convinced that he and thousands of middle-class people like him have found a way to fill it. The national motto here is said to be ''Don't get involved,'' but in a matter of weeks a new and increasingly assertive civic movement known as the ''self-convened neighborhood assemblies'' has sprung up. On street corners and in parks, ordinary Argentines are now meeting after work and on weekends not just to vent their wrath at politicians but to organize and to debate solutions to the country's crisis.

headline.main: Argentine Leader Seeks Broad Powers in Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: After urging Argentines to stop buying foreign goods and begin ''protecting what is ours,'' the country's new president, Eduardo Duhalde, sent Congress a ''public emergency law'' today that would give him sweeping powers to deal with the economic cri

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER

docs.lead_paragraph: After urging Argentines to stop buying foreign goods and begin ''protecting what is ours,'' the country's new president, Eduardo Duhalde, sent Congress a ''public emergency law'' today that would give him sweeping powers to deal with the economic crisis that has immobilized the country for the last month. The legislation would end a decade-long policy of setting the value of the Argentine peso at one American dollar and using the two currencies almost interchangeably.

headline.main: Economic Crisis Offers Hints of Executive Style

docs.snippet: President-elect Barack Obama has shown an inclination to set the broad terms for debate, and then to delegate details to advisers and Congress.

byline.original: By JACKIE CALMES

docs.lead_paragraph: He will not formally take power for almost six weeks, but President-elect Barack Obama is already showing some glimpses of how he will wield it. Despite his professed resolve to stay at arms length from governance during the transition, the economic crisis has forced him to play a more active role -- nowhere more so than in Washington's scramble to avert the collapse of the Big Three automakers with a federal lifeline.

headline.main: European Leaders Looking for Common Ground in an Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: The government plans to cut taxes and increase public spending despite a budget deficit that was among the largest of any developed nation.

byline.original: By JULIA WERDIGIER

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to spend its way out of its first recession in 17 years, the British government announced on Monday a plan to cut taxes and increase public spending despite a budget deficit that was among the largest of any developed nation. As part of the 20 billion ($30.3 billion) package presented to Parliament by the chancellor of the Exchequer, Alistair Darling, the government plans to reduce the sales tax to 15 percent, from 17.5 percent, for 13 months through 2009; help homeowners struggling with their mortgage payments and further support pensioners and small businesses.

headline.main: Newest Veterans Hit Hard by Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: A combination of factors including unemployment and injury has forced many veterans into foreclosure.

byline.original: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

docs.lead_paragraph: After a mortar sent Andrew Spurlock hurtling off a roof in Iraq, ending his Army career in 2006, the seasoned infantryman set aside bitterness over his back injury and began to chart his life in storybook fashion: a new house, a job as a police officer and more children. ''We had a budget and a plan,'' said Mr. Spurlock, 29, a father of three, who with his wife, Michelle, hoped to avoid the pitfalls of his transition from Ramadi, Iraq, to Apopka, Fla.

headline.main: Leaders Move Toward Conferences on Economic Crisis

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush and European leaders, who have been tussling over whether to revamp the regulatory framework for global finance, agreed Saturday night to take steps toward a series of international meetings to address the economic crisis, the White House said. After a private dinner at Camp David, Mr. Bush, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and the president of the European Commission, Jos Manuel Barroso, issued a joint statement saying they agreed to ''reach out to other world leaders'' to propose an international summit meeting to be held soon after the United States presidential election, with the possibility of more gatherings after that.

Two weeks ago, she said, she had planned to vote for Senator John McCain of Arizona, the Republican, who impressed her with his knowledge of the world. But as the economy began to scare her more than terrorism, she reconsidered.

headline.main: VAST BAILOUT BY U.S. PROPOSED IN BID TO STEM ECONOMIC CRISIS

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON -- The head of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve began discussions on Thursday with Congressional leaders on what could become the biggest bailout in United States history.      While details remain to be worked out, the plan is likely

byline.original: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS; Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The head of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve began discussions on Thursday with Congressional leaders on what could become the biggest bailout in United States history. While details remain to be worked out, the plan is likely to authorize the government to buy distressed mortgages at deep discounts from banks and other institutions. The proposal could result in the most direct commitment of taxpayer funds so far in the financial crisis that Fed and Treasury officials say is the worst they have ever seen.

docs.abstract: Colleges around country are embracing financial crisis as valuable teaching tool; academics say they cannot recall time when so much of curriculum has had to be revised so quickly to reflect sweeping developments in economy; business schools and economics departments are at forefront of overhaul, unveiling new courses and revamping old ones; professors are also reworking syllabuses to include material on crisis and its aftermath; photo (M)

headline.main: Colleges Turn the Economic Crisis Into a Lesson Plan

docs.snippet: At Columbia, Cornell and other universities, new and revamped courses are exploring the lessons of the meltdown.

byline.original: By LISA W. FODERARO

docs.lead_paragraph: Steven Fraser, a professor of American studies at Columbia University, has taught the cultural history of Wall Street for years, usually bringing his students up to the 1990s. But this fall, with the financial crisis providing an irresistible new coda to the course, he extended the timeline to include the drama, intrigue and pain of the past two years. ''The class is struck by the similarities between today and the darker periods of Wall Street's past, for example in the Gilded Age -- the meltdown, the bonuses, the reckless speculation, the impact of Wall Street's behavior on the rest of society,'' he said. ''We compare the confidence man of 1840 to the confidence man of today.''

docs.snippet: Facing demise last year, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has found renewed purpose in stabilizing eastern European economies.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH

docs.lead_paragraph: As recently as last year, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development seemed like a relic of the post-cold war era. One of the nations providing the bank's financial backing, Australia, asked for its money back, while one of the new European Union members, the Czech Republic, became the first country to leave its lending programs. But the bank, which helped shepherd Soviet-bloc eastern European command economies into the free-market era, has found a renewed sense of purpose in stabilizing these economies and protecting their hard-won progress.

headline.main: Our Current Global Economic Crisis: The Prequel

docs.snippet: “The Ascent of Money,” which begins Wednesday on PBS, explores various monetary crises and financial instruments that altered history for better or worse.

byline.original: By GINIA BELLAFANTE

docs.lead_paragraph: In ''The Ascent of Money,'' boldly subtitled ''A Financial History of the World,'' the host Niall Ferguson makes many costume changes, choosing, for instance, a loose-fitting butter-cream blazer to amble around the Jewish quarter of Venice and explain the evolution of money lending. In cooler climates he prefers roll-neck pullovers or a trench. In Santiago (to discuss Chilean reform) or New Orleans (to cover the economic repercussions of Hurricane Katrina), he wears cotton shirts of such a low thread count that they are vaguely see-through, and he leaves them unbuttoned enough to suggest that if he hadn't become the Laurence A. Tisch professor of history at Harvard, he might have turned into Rick Springfield. In promotional material for this PBS series (which begins on Wednesday and continues over the next three weeks), Mr. Ferguson adorns himself with a single gold-hoop earring that he forgoes for the documentary itself. I was disappointed not to see it, imagining that perhaps he had dressed himself according to Coco Chanel's maxim that when accessorizing, you should always take off the last thing you put on.

headline.main: Economic Crisis Pits the European Union Against Its Members

docs.snippet: European leaders, preoccupied with domestic politics, are fighting over how to combat the economic slump, protecting jobs at home at the expense of fellow members.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER; Nadim Audi contributed reporting from Amiens and Calais, France, and George Calin from Bucharest, Romania

multimedia.caption: Fracturing on Economic Lines
multimedia.credit: The 27 countries of the European Union form a powerful economic bloc. But the current financial crisis has begun to fracture the alliance, with stronger economies protecting their national interests. Maps showing a range of impact across the European Union for three economic indicators.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The 27 countries of the European Union form a powerful economic bloc. But the current financial crisis has begun to fracture the alliance, with stronger economies protecting their national interests. Maps showing a range of impact across the European Union for three economic indicators.

docs.lead_paragraph: The European Union is an extraordinary experiment in shared sovereignty, creating a zone of peace that now stretches from Britain to the Balkans. The union of 27 countries is the world's most formidable economic bloc, incorporating 491 million people in an integrated market that produces nearly a third more than the United States. But the global economic crisis has made it clear that Europe remains less than the sum of its parts.

headline.main: Economic Crisis Is Prompting a Rethinking in Europe

docs.snippet: The countries that have done the best to soften the blow for workers are those with a tradition of social partnership among employers, trade unions and government, but political support for further economic openness has evaporated.

byline.original: By PAUL TAYLOR

docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- Unlike the situation in the 1930s, there are no hunger marches or tent cities of the homeless and jobless in the biggest European economic slump since the Great Depression hit the United States. Welfare states built after World War II, and labor market regulation in many Western European countries, have cushioned workers and their families so far from the full force of the collapse of banks, the credit squeeze and a deep recession.

headline.main: Malnutrition and the Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: My Sunday column is the last from my win-a-trip journey with Paul Bowers, and it looks at malnutrition - which has worsened because of the global economic crisis. I also think we often tend to conceive of malnutrition incorrectly, looking only for ki

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KRISTOF

docs.lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is the last from my win-a-trip journey with Paul Bowers, and it looks at malnutrition -- which has worsened because of the global economic crisis. I also think we often tend to conceive of malnutrition incorrectly, looking only for kids who are starving overall, rather than those who are starving for particular nutrients. Some of the most cost-effective ways to help fight poverty involve the provision of micronutrients such as iron, iodine, vitamin A.

headline.main: Economic Crisis Raises Fears Extremism in Western Countries

docs.snippet: A survey conducted by Harris Interactive for the International Herald Tribune and France 24 showed that a majority in Western countries through political extremism would rise as a result of the crisis.

byline.original: By JOHN C. FREED

docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- A solid majority of people in the major Western democracies expect a rise in political extremism in their countries as a result of the economic crisis, according to a new poll. Even in the United States and Italy, the two countries whose citizens are least likely to hold that view, fully 53 percent of those surveyed say more extremism is ''certain to happen'' or ''probable'' in the next three years, according to the poll, conducted by Harris Interactive for the International Herald Tribune and France 24. The number rises to 65 percent in Britain and Germany, with about 60 percent expressing that view in the other two countries surveyed, France and Spain.

headline.main: Link to Economic Crisis Is Vital to Obama Agenda

docs.snippet: Team Obama has cast his initiatives on health care, energy, education and the auto and financial industries as responses to the downturn, but time is not on his side politically.

byline.original: By JOHN HARWOOD

docs.lead_paragraph: Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, encapsulated President Obama's goal long before the first of the First 100 Days: ''Never let a serious crisis go to waste.'' That post-election formulation remains the fulcrum for the legislative battle only now starting in earnest. Over the Next 100 Days, the outcome may turn on how convincingly the White House preserves the link between Mr. Obama's agenda and the painful recession he inherited.

headline.main: Workers Rally to Protest Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: PARIS -- Rising unemployment, static wages and anger at national governments over the depth of the financial crisis brought hundreds of thousands of demonstrators onto the streets of Europe on Friday to mark the traditional workers' May Day holiday.

byline.original: By MATTHEW SALTMARSH

docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- Rising unemployment, static wages and anger at national governments over the depth of the financial crisis brought hundreds of thousands of demonstrators onto the streets of Europe on Friday to mark the traditional workers' May Day holiday. But though there were tense confrontations and sporadic incidents of violence reported in Germany, Greece and Turkey, the protests were generally peaceful, and in some areas there was a calm that suggested that people had used the holiday to extend their weekend.

headline.main: Asian Data Underscores Severity of Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: HONG KONG -- As world leaders assemble in London for the Group of 20 summit this week, the latest  evidence of the severity of the economic crisis emerged from Asia on Wednesday, with business confidence in Japan plummeting to a record low, South Kor

byline.original: By BETTINA WASSENER

docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG -- As world leaders assemble in London for the Group of 20 summit this week, the latest evidence of the severity of the economic crisis emerged from Asia on Wednesday, with business confidence in Japan plummeting to a record low, South Korean exports falling for a fifth consecutive month and a manufacturing index deteriorating in China. The data from three of Asia's largest economies underscored a picture of slumping exports and production, and hammered home the point that despite some recent signs that the situation may at least have stopped worsening in parts of the world, the global economy remains in the middle of the worst downturn in decades.

headline.main: Economic Crisis Stirs Sony Pictures To Cut Current Staff by Nearly 250

docs.snippet: Sony Pictures says it will trim 3-and-a-half percent of its workforce, which amounts to slightly less than 250 jobs.

byline.original: By MICHAEL CIEPLY

docs.lead_paragraph: Staff cuts, having hit nearly everywhere in Hollywood, have finally struck Sony Pictures. In a letter sent to the studio staff on Tuesday afternoon, Michael Lynton and Amy Pascal, who oversee the studio, said the company's worldwide work force was in for a 3-and-a-half percent reduction.

headline.main: Economic Crisis Complicates California's Goals on Climate

docs.snippet: California was one of the first states to enact legislation to tackle global warming. But the state is also proving how hard it can be to carry out such laws, especially now.

byline.original: By FELICITY BARRINGER

docs.lead_paragraph: Only a few years ago, CalPortland planned on keeping its plant here operating as long as Mount Slover's limestone held out. For more than a century, Colton's kilns and crushing machines have been churning out cement for the streets and buildings of Los Angeles. But the company says the plant's future is now uncertain. The recession has sent cement prices plunging, lowered profits and forced CalPortland's drivers to cut back on hours. And the company says it faces new expenses: the cost of meeting California's new requirements that manufacturers take steps to curb emissions of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas linked to global warming.

headline.main: Gibe by Gibe, French-Czech Feud Impairs Europe's Response to Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: The bitterness at the top of the union is damaging the alliance’s ability to cope with the economic crisis.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER

docs.lead_paragraph: The Czech president, Vaclav Klaus, jokes about Nicolas Sarkozy's desire to be Europe's ''permanent chairperson.'' Mr. Sarkozy, the president of France, says rather patronizingly of the Czechs, ''They're doing what they can.'' It may seem like a round of adolescent insults more suited to high school, but the bitterness between the last holder of the European Union presidency, France, and the current one, the Czech Republic, is damaging the alliance's ability to cope with the severe economic crisis.

headline.main: Global Economic Crisis Poses Top Threat to U.S., Spy Chief Warns

docs.snippet: Dennis C. Blair said economic turmoil and the instability it could ignite has outpaced terrorism as the worst threat.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI

docs.lead_paragraph: The new director of national intelligence told Congress on Thursday that global economic turmoil and the instability it could ignite had outpaced terrorism as the most urgent threat facing the United States. The assessment underscored concern inside America's intelligence agencies not only about the fallout from the economic crisis around the globe, but also about long-term harm to America's reputation. The crisis that began in American markets has already ''increased questioning of U.S. stewardship of the global economy,'' the intelligence chief, Dennis C. Blair, said in prepared testimony.

Fuld Jr. of Lehman Brothers held forth on the state of the global economy before mesmerized journalists and cowering subordinates while other Wall Street stars mingled after-hours with the likes of Claudia Schiffer, the German supermodel.

headline.main: Japan and Korea Vow Unity In Confronting Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: The financial crisis prompted South Korea and Japan to set aside historical disputes on Monday and agree to cooperate to meet immediate economic challenges.

byline.original: By CHOE SANG-HUN

docs.lead_paragraph: The global financial crisis prompted the leaders of South Korea and Japan to set aside their countries' century of disputes on Monday and agree to cooperate to meet immediate economic challenges. But Korean victims of Japan's World War II brutalities voiced distress at the summit meeting and joint news conference of President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea and Prime Minister Taro Aso of Japan. They accused Mr. Lee of sacrificing the South's national pride for short-term economic gains.

docs.abstract: World leaders' pledge of $20 billion to help the poorest farmers around the globe has fallen short a year and a half later; Pres Obama's development efforts have met with numerous obstacles (M)

headline.main: Economic Crisis Sidelines Fate of the World's Poorest

docs.snippet: World leaders’ pledge of $20 billion to help the poorest farmers around the globe has, a year and a half later, fallen woefully short.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Last year, after a personal appeal from President Obama in which he cited his own family's experiences in Kenya, world leaders gathered at the Italian hill town of L'Aquila pledged $20 billion over three years to help millions of the world's poorest farmers grow enough food to feed themselves -- a ''landmark achievement'' organizers said in a report. A year and a half later, barely $1 billion has come in, mostly from the United States. Canada, Spain, South Korea and the Gates Foundation recently promised around $400 million, but many donors have been shifting old aid pledges into the new fund, and counting them twice.

headline.main: Spain's Socialists and Unions, Battered by Economic Crisis, Struggle to Adapt

docs.snippet: Spanish workers are trying to oppose new austerity measures without significantly damaging an ally, Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero.

byline.original: By RACHEL DONADIO and RAPHAEL MINDER

docs.lead_paragraph: MADRID -- With 20 percent unemployment and a series of unpopular new austerity measures, Spain would seem a natural breeding ground for labor unrest. But by most accounts, a general strike late last month was more a demonstration of discontent than a sign of trouble brewing. Analysts said it appeared to be a well-choreographed effort by unions to show that they were upset with the austerity measures without significantly damaging an ally, Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, who is at his weakest point since being elected in 2004.

headline.main: European Union Prepares for Economic Crisis Meeting

docs.snippet: Jos Manuel Barroso’s economic agenda risks being overwhelmed by the debt crisis that has swept across the Continent.

byline.original: By STEPHEN CASTLE

docs.lead_paragraph: STRASBOURG -- As the European Parliament gathers to install a new team of commissioners Tuesday to work with Jos Manuel Barroso, president of the European Commission, in his second term, Europe's economic modernization agenda risks being overwhelmed by one issue it would rather not have to tackle: The debt crises that has swept across the Continent. With the markets taking fright at budget deficits in Greece, Portugal and Spain, and sapping confidence in Europe's single currency, the need for strong leadership within the 27-member European Union has rarely been greater. But the crisis has raised questions about the European Union's ability to deal with the structural problems that have led to a rift between richer and poor nations within the eurozone.

headline.main: Battered by Economic Crisis, Greeks Turn to Barter Networks

docs.snippet: Greeks squeezed by wage cuts, tax increases and growing fears about the euro have looked for creative ways to cope with a radically changing economic landscape.

byline.original: By RACHEL DONADIO; Dimitris Bounias contributed reporting from Volos and Athens

docs.lead_paragraph: VOLOS, Greece -- The first time he bought eggs, milk and jam at an outdoor market using not euros but an informal barter currency, Theodoros Mavridis, an unemployed electrician, was thrilled. ''I felt liberated, I felt free for the first time,'' Mr. Mavridis said in a recent interview at a cafe in this port city in central Greece. ''I instinctively reached into my pocket, but there was no need to.''

headline.main: Economic Crisis Will Leave Scars That Last for Years

docs.snippet: Prolonged economic slowdowns make their mark not only through the pain they cause while we are in the middle of them; they have a permanent, and largely malignant, impact.

byline.original: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

docs.lead_paragraph: We all know there are three important things about real estate: location, location, location. That double repetition, which the late and great word sleuth William Safire traced back to a 1926 Chicago Tribune classified ad, is still with us because it is succinct and true. You can think about the economic and political woes of the Western world today in the same way. It's all about jobs, jobs, jobs.

headline.main: America's economic crisis has clear political roots

docs.snippet: By nearly every recent measure — growth, consumer spending, manufacturing, house prices and stock prices — the American economy is struggling.
docs.lead_paragraph: By nearly every recent measure -- growth, consumer spending, manufacturing, house prices and stock prices -- the American economy is struggling. The jobs report for July, released on Friday, was a bit better than expected, but still grim. The question now is whether Washington will move beyond the wrongheaded focus on budget cuts -- the last thing a faltering economy needs -- to job creation.

docs.abstract: Michael Kinsley reviews HBO movie Too Big to Fail starring Topher Grace and William Hurt; photos (M)

headline.main: Economic Crisis Unfurls In Hushed Suspense

docs.snippet: The HBO film “Too Big to Fail,” based on a book about the financial crisis of 2008, uses every cinematic trick in the book, but ultimately succeeds because we know that the danger was real.

byline.original: By MICHAEL KINSLEY

docs.lead_paragraph: It can't be easy to create a financial thriller. There's no blood, there are (usually) no bodies. How do you create excitement when most of the action consists of middle-aged white men in conservative suits talking on the phone, and the closest thing to a car chase is a stately procession of big black Town Cars? How often can you show people peering at spreadsheets and recoiling in alarm? What do you do when the scandal itself might as well be labeled ''Too Complicated to Understand''? The HBO film ''Too Big to Fail,'' based on the book of the same name by the reporter Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times, about the financial crisis of 2008, uses every cinematic trick in the book, but ultimately succeeds because we know that the danger was real. One way to create an atmosphere of crisis is simply to have your characters assert that it's a crisis. In ''Too Big to Fail,'' directed by Curtis Hanson (''L.A. Confidential''), people are always saying things like, ''If we don't do this now, we won't have an economy on Monday.'' There's also a lot of staring soulfully through windows or into mirrors. The hero of Mr. Sorkin's version of events, Treasury secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., played by William Hurt, indicates the terrible stress he's under by talking ever-more softly. The Federal Reserve chairman Ben S. Bernanke, played by Paul Giamatti, does the same. As things get worse, the conversation at their weekly breakfast meetings degenerates into a low rumble.

docs.abstract: Economic crisis in Belarus deepens when its currency plunges in value after the Central Bank lifts restrictions on the exchange rate; photo (M)

headline.main: Belarus Economic Crisis Deepens as Currency Plunges

docs.snippet: An economic crisis deepened in the former Soviet republic as the Central Bank lifted restrictions on the exchange rate, setting off a collapse of the ruble.

byline.original: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

docs.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW -- An economic crisis in Belarus deepened Wednesday when its currency plunged in value after the Central Bank lifted restrictions on the exchange rate. The rule change, and a subsequent drop in the value of the ruble, had been anticipated. But the speed of the currency's collapse -- by about 25 percent against the dollar in one day -- jarred nerves and sent a ripple through European markets, though a small one. Belarus's eccentric politics have largely isolated the country economically.

headline.main: New Japan PM: Saving Economic Crisis Top Mission

Photo (M)t

headline.main: Results of French and Greek Elections Could Signal Shift on Economic Crisis

docs.snippet: The outcome of Sunday’s elections is likely to be another blow to a German-designed austerity plan to cure the euro zone’s debt and banking crisis.

byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER; Maa de la Baume contributed reporting from Paris, and Niki Kitsantonis from Athens

docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- France and Greece vote Sunday in elections that will be closely watched for the future of the European Union and the euro. The votes will once again highlight the emerging crux of the euro crisis: Will democratic politics offer a solution to the economic crisis or just make it worse? Anxieties are rising again over the shared currency, and these elections are likely to be another blow to a German-designed austerity plan to cure the euro zone's debt and banking crisis. If the French Socialist candidate, Franois Hollande, wins the presidency, as the polls suggest, he plans to challenge Germany, vowing to renegotiate a European Union treaty mandating deficit and debt limits in order to add a new emphasis on economic growth.

docs.abstract: Economic downturn that has shaken Europe for the last three years has also swept away the foundations of once-sturdy lives, leading to an alarming spike in suicide rates; especially in the most fragile nations, small-business owners and entrepreneurs are increasingly taking their own lives. Photos (M)/

headline.main: Increasingly, Suicide 'by Economic Crisis' Is a Symptom of the Downturn in Europe

docs.snippet: In countries hardest hit by the downturn, including Ireland and Italy, small-business men and entrepreneurs are increasingly taking their own lives.

byline.original: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and DOREEN CARVAJAL; Elisabetta Povoledo reported from Treviso, and Doreen Carvajal from Lahardane, Ireland

docs.lead_paragraph: TREVISO, Italy -- On New Year's Eve, Antonio Tamiozzo, 53, hanged himself in the warehouse of his construction business near Vicenza, after several debtors did not pay what they owed him. Three weeks earlier, Giovanni Schiavon, 59, a contractor, shot himself in the head at the headquarters of his debt-ridden construction company on the outskirts of Padua. As he faced the bleak prospect of ordering Christmas layoffs at his family firm of two generations, he wrote a last message: ''Sorry, I cannot take it anymore.''

headline.main: Economic Crisis Adds to Dangers on Egypt's New Political Path

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )

docs.snippet: With mounting debts, negligible growth and dwindling foreign reserves, Egypt’s military rulers and the new Islamist-led Parliament face a crisis that could undermine the political transition.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH

docs.lead_paragraph: CAIRO -- After a year of unending turmoil and military rule, Egypt faces an acute financial crisis that could undermine its political transition and pose a defining challenge to Islamists now coming to power. With mounting debts, negligible economic growth and dwindling foreign reserves, the military rulers and the new Islamist-led Parliament now confront some difficult choices, beginning with an all but inevitable further devaluation of Egypt's currency that could send the prices of food and other goods soaring.

headline.main: Egypt's Economic Crisis

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )

docs.snippet: Worsening economic conditions are sabotaging hopes for a democratic future. The new government must make reforms if it wants to spur investment and growth.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the year since President Hosni Mubarak was ousted, Egypt has faced many challenges: the military-led government's brutality against protesters and pro-democracy groups, its resistance to handing power to civilian leaders and the rise of Islamists in the country's first free elections. Now worsening economic conditions are further sabotaging hopes for a democratic future. The country's foreign currency reserves have fallen from a peak of $36 billion to about $10 billion and could run out entirely by March. The currency is under severe pressure, and a steep drop in the exchange rate could bring painful inflation and more social unrest. Youth unemployment is about 25 percent, a dangerous situation where 60 percent of the citizens are 30 and under.
